title: Mohammed A. Aldouri
text:
Mohammed A. Aldouri () (born 12 September 1941) was the Permanent Representative of <a href="Iraq">Iraq</a> to the <a href="United%20Nations">United Nations</a> from 2001 to 2003.
Early life.
Born in <a href="Baghdad">Baghdad</a>, he attended <a href="Baghdad%20University">Baghdad University</a> and earned a <a href="bachelor%27s%20degree">bachelor's degree</a> in <a href="law">law</a> in 1964. In 1973, Aldouri received a <a href="Ph.D.">Ph.D.</a> in <a href="public%20law">public law</a> from <a href="France">France</a>’s <a href="University%20of%20Burgundy">Dijon University</a>. He was <a href="dean%20%28education%29">dean</a> of the Law College of Baghdad University from 1983 to 1998 while he served as a <a href="professor">professor</a> of <a href="international%20law">international law</a>. 
Career.
Aldouri was a member of the Iraqi <a href="delegation">delegation</a> to the United Nations from 1980 to 1984. From 1994 to 1996, Aldouri was head of the Legal Department and Human Rights Department of the Iraqi <a href="Foreign%20Ministry">Foreign Ministry</a>. He served as Iraq’s Representative to the United Nations Office at <a href="Geneva">Geneva</a> from 1999 up until his appointment as Iraq's Ambassador to the United Nations in February 2001. Before and during the <a href="2003%20invasion%20of%20Iraq">2003 invasion of Iraq</a>, Aldouri gained international attention for his harsh criticisms of the US and vigorous defenses of <a href="Saddam%20Hussein">Saddam Hussein</a>’s <a href="regime">regime</a>. On April 9, Aldouri became the first high-ranking Iraqi official to admit that Hussein’s government had collapsed. On April 11, Aldouri resigned as Ambassador to the UN and left the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>. 
Since resigning, Aldouri has called Saddam Hussein a "tyrant" and apologized for some of the "tough" remarks he had made about the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> while ambassador. However, Aldouri has also become a major critic of the US presence in Iraq and has called for the withdrawal of foreign troops from the country. He currently resides in <a href="Dubai">Dubai</a>, <a href="United%20Arab%20Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a>.
In a television interview that aired September 22, 2010 on Decision Makers TV, he openly speculated about the <a href="9/11%20conspiracy%20theories">possibility that the United States may have been complicit in the events of September 11 attacks in 2001</a>. He asserted, "The tyranny of the U.S., and its goals in ruling the world and taking over the entire world -- from north to south and from east to west -- were, in my opinion, the indirect cause of the events of 9/11, if not the direct cause." He claimed that many people "have doubted the ability of Al-Qaeda to carry out such a momentous, earth-shattering event... Many people claim that the U.S. intelligence -- or at least part of the Pentagon -- was behind 9/11. But only God knows."
